user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_system_cpu_count:
```c
int
mhd_tool_get_system_cpu_count (void)
{
  int res;

  /* Try specialised APIs first */
  res = mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_special_api_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  /* Try sysctl*(). This is typically a direct interface to
     kernel values. */
  res = mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  /* Try sysconf() as the last resort as this is a generic interface
     which can be implemented by parsing system files. */
  res = mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_ ();
#if ! defined(__linux__) && ! defined(__GLIBC__)
  if (0 < res)
    return res;
#else  /* __linux__ || __GLIBC__ */
  if (2 < res)
    return res;
  if (0 < res)
  {
    /* '1' or '2' could a be fallback number.
     * See get_nprocs_fallback() in glibc
       sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/getsysstats.c */

    int proc_cpu_count;

    proc_cpu_count = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count ();
    if (proc_cpu_count == res)
    {
      /* The detected number of CPUs available for the process
         is equal to the detected number of system CPUs.
         Assume detected number is correct. */
      return res;
    }
  }
#endif /* __linux__ || __GLIBC__  */

  /* Try available fallbacks */

  res = mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_fallback_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  res = mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_fallback_ ();
#if ! defined(__linux__) && ! defined(__GLIBC__)
  if (0 < res)
    return res;
#else  /* __linux__ || __GLIBC__ */
  if (2 < res)
    return res;
#endif /* __linux__ || __GLIBC__  */

  return -1; /* Cannot detect */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other parts of the function appear to be normal, conditional and reachable depending on run‑time return values or build configuration, and therefore do not by themselves indicate unreachable code: the early returns immediately after calls to mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_special_api_(), mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_(), and mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_fallback_() are reachable whenever those functions return >0; the final return -1 is reachable if no detection succeeded. The only parts that merit investigation for potential unreachable code are the conditional compilation branches and the Linux-specific handling (shown above), because depending on the defined macros (__linux__/__GLIBC__) or the numeric ranges used (e.g. the separate checks for >2 and >0) portions of those branches could be effectively excluded or never executed across project builds and should be reviewed for unintended dead code.
